sections.title: Planning first, surgery second
sections.body: Dental implants replace missing teeth using a small titanium post that supports a crown, bridge, or implant-retained denture. Before surgery, we assess your mouth, review your medical history, and use CBCT imaging and digital scans to map bone, nerves, bite, and the intended tooth shape. This helps us explain suitable options, likely timing, and whether staged steps such as bone grafting or sinus lift assessment may be needed. If implants are not appropriate, we will discuss alternatives such as bridges or removable solutions.
bullets: Fixed tooth replacement for suitable patients
Clear options and costs explained upfront
Local care in Shoreham-by-Sea, near Brighton

sections.title: Why patients trust us
items: Experienced implant clinicians — Implant care here is clinician-led and planning-focused, not sales-led.
CBCT + guided surgery — We plan in 3D and, where appropriate, place implants using guided surgery for accuracy.
Transparent options — If implants are not right for you, we will explain alternatives clearly.
High-quality materials — We use established implant systems and restorative materials.

sections.title: A step-by-step approach
sections.body:
Every implant case is different. Some patients have sufficient bone and space and can proceed without additional stages. Others require phased treatment, for example bone grafting or sinus lift assessment. The consultation is where we outline the safest sequence, expected timings, and costs.

We also cover practical considerations: appointments, healing periods, aftercare, and long-term maintenance.
bullets: Design for cleaning and long-term gum health
Consider bite forces, not just appearance

sections.title: What is a dental implant?
sections.body:
A dental implant is a small titanium post that replaces the root of a missing tooth. Once integrated with the bone, we attach a connector (abutment) followed by a crown, bridge, or denture.

Implants sit in living bone near nerves and sinuses. We plan in 3D to assess bone volume and quality, nerve position in the lower jaw, sinus position in the upper jaw, bite forces and spacing, and final tooth position and shape.

sections.title: Suitability and case selection
items: Implants may be suitable if you have one or more missing teeth and want a fixed solution similar to a natural tooth.
Healthy gums matter — or gum disease should be controlled before treatment.
You need to be able to maintain excellent oral hygiene for long-term implant health.
We are cautious in smokers, uncontrolled diabetes, active gum disease, and certain medication or medical histories.
These factors do not always rule implants out but they do influence planning and risk management.

sections.title: Implant treatment, step by step
items: 1) Consultation + planning — We assess your mouth, discuss goals and options, and plan using digital scans and CBCT.
2) Implant placement — The implant is placed in a planned position, usually under local anaesthetic (sedation options available where appropriate).
3) Healing + integration — Bone heals around the implant. This typically takes a few months, depending on the case.
4) Final restoration — We fit the crown, bridge, or denture once the implant is stable.
5) Maintenance — Implants require ongoing hygiene care and regular reviews.
sections.strapline: Timelines vary by healing, bone, and case complexity. We set expectations clearly after planning.

sections.title: CBCT + digital scanning
sections.body:
We use 3D imaging (CBCT) and digital scans for precise planning. This helps us avoid anatomical structures, confirm available bone, and aim for a predictable final tooth position.

Where appropriate, guided surgery allows implant placement using a custom surgical guide. This supports accuracy and a controlled procedure.

sections.title: Important risks we discuss
items: Infection
Failure to integrate
Gum recession
Peri-implantitis (inflammation around implants)
Damage to nerves or sinuses is rare, and planning reduces risk.

sections.title: Long-term success depends on care
items: Daily cleaning, including along the gumline.
Professional hygiene maintenance.
Managing gum inflammation.
Avoiding smoking.
Protecting against heavy bite forces, sometimes with a night guard.

faqs.question: How long do implants last?
faqs.answer: Many implants last for years. Longevity depends on gum health, hygiene, bite forces, and maintenance.

faqs.question: Is implant treatment painful?
faqs.answer: Implants are usually placed under local anaesthetic. Post-operative discomfort is typically manageable with standard pain relief.

faqs.question: How long does treatment take?
faqs.answer: Some cases are straightforward. Others require staged steps. We will provide a realistic timeline after planning.

faqs.question: Do I need a CBCT scan?
faqs.answer: For most implant cases, a CBCT scan is recommended for safe and accurate planning.

faqs.question: Can you place implants if I’ve had a tooth missing for a long time?
faqs.answer: Often yes, although bone changes over time. Planning will determine whether grafting or other steps are needed.

faqs.question: What are the alternatives to implants?
faqs.answer: Alternatives may include bridges, dentures, or leaving the space in some cases. We will explain the advantages and limitations during consultation.

faqs.question: What if I’m nervous?
faqs.answer: We provide step-by-step care and can discuss sedation options where appropriate.

sections.title: Implant care at St Mary’s House — clinician-led
sections.body:
Dr Nick Maxwell leads implant planning and placement at St Mary’s House Dental Care. He holds an MSc in Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry and a PGDip in Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics, and has completed implant surgical training including intensive implant placement training in Cairo (2014).

He also designs and 3D prints surgical guides for guided implant placement, combining clinical judgement with digital planning where appropriate. The focus is careful case selection, clear communication, and long-term maintainability.
bullets: Implant planning and placement led by Dr Nick Maxwell
MSc in Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry with a PGDip in Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics
Implant surgical training including intensive placement training in Cairo (2014)
Guided surgery supported by in-house 3D planning and printed guides

sections.title: A clear way to decide
sections.body:
Implants can be a suitable solution — but the right choice depends on your priorities: fixed versus removable options, speed versus staged healing, and what can be maintained long-term.

At your assessment we’ll answer three practical questions:
bullets: Are implants sensible and safe in your mouth?
What are the realistic options (and alternatives)?
What would we recommend if you were family?
No pressure, no hype — just a clear plan you can understand.

sections.title: Book an implant assessment
sections.strapline: If you’re considering implants, we’ll assess suitability, explain options and costs, and help you decide with confidence.

reassurance_intent.label: Map next steps such as Aftercare and hygiene
